headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2014
componenttext:
Good morning, and good evening. Welcome to Lenovo's Q3 earnings webcast. This is Gary Ng, VP in Investor Relations at Lenovo. Before we start, let me introduce our management team with us today. We have our Chairman and CEO, Mr. Yuanqing Yang; and our CFO, Mr. Wong Wai Ming. We will first start with our management presentation. After that, we will take your questions.
Now let me turn it over to Yuanqing.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2014
componenttext:
Hello, everyone, and happy lunar new year. I know you most likely have questions on our recent M&A deals, but before we go there, I want to talk about our outstanding performance last quarter. 
This last quarter, Lenovo delivered both record revenue and record profit. Our revenue surpassed USD 10 billion for the first time at nearly USD 11 billion. Even better, our net profit reached USD 265 million, up 30% year-on-year. We continue delivering our promise of improving our profitability. Our strong performance is the direct result of our clear strategy and consistent execution. We are focused on protecting our core PC business while aggressively are taking growth in PC Plus areas, including tablets, smartphones, servers and storage.
For PCs in a very tough marketing environment, we not only protected our #1 position with a record share of 18.5%, but also at the same time, our PC operation profit grew by 27% year-on-year. Even more impressive, our strong PC results were driven by balanced performance worldwide, strengthening both volume and profit.
In China, we improved our operation margin by one more point to reach 7.1% from 5.8% a year ago. In EMEA, we gained 4 points of market share year-on-year. In Asia Pacific, we regained the #1 position in the region. And in Americas, we were the fastest-growing company at certain one point premier to the market. While we continue to successfully protect our PC business, our attack in PC Plus business also had a very strong quarter. Our tablet sales volume was up more than 325% year-on-year to a record of almost 3.4 million units, with 4.3% worldwide market share. Every geo had a strong growth, with EMEA leading the way, growing almost 4.5x year-on-year. 
And our star products, the Yoga Tablet was particularly popular among customers worldwide. Our smartphone business continues to grow globally. Our worldwide smartphone sales volume grew almost 50% year-on-year, driven by hyper growth in Asia-Pacific and in EMEA.  Outside of China, for the first time, we sold 2 million smartphones.
Overall, we sold nearly 14 million, maintaining our strong position at the #4 worldwide. We will build on this momentum and capture the 4G opportunity, especially in China with our newest products. Even more, last month, we announced 2 deals aligned with our long-term strategy, that we will significantly increase our PC Plus business. We know these are absolutely the right investments to secure our future. Our plan is clear, and we are now building the foundation of growth for the next decade. First, we announced a deal to acquire IBM x86 server business. This deal would immediately make Lenovo the #3 player in this area globally and would make us the leader in key growth markets around the world. We will fully leverage our strength in supply chain to bring down the costs and are confident we can turn the server business into a more profitable business than PCs. This will definitely help improve our overall profitability. We also will draw on our strong channel relationships to drive hyper growth, particularly in China where demand for servers is still very strong.
Meanwhile, our planned acquisition of Motorola Mobility creates a perfect fit with our global growth strategy in smartphones. With this agreement, we will become a much stronger #3 smartphone company in the world. And already, we are mapping out a thorough integration and turnaround plan.
I'm confident that from day one after closing, we will be able to realize the synergies that are tangible and substantial, as well as introduce new products to the market. We believe that we not only can achieve significant savings from lower material costs but also can reduce E/R with our global scale. at the same time, in the iconic Motorola brand, we will definitely introduce rich and more innovative products. Those products will not only serve customers in North America and Latin America but also will be reintroduced back to China and other emerging markets where we believe customers will embrace Motorola once again.
For both of these deals, our top priority now is to work through the regulatory process and obtain approvals. We have a good understanding of this process, and we will be open and transparent with all regulatory agencies around the world. We have very strong track records in our other M&A activities, and we welcome the process as an important next step. In fact, we have reshaped our organization to accelerate the integration process once these deals close. We have created 4 business groups. The PC business group, we are focused on protecting our leadership and the profitability in PCs. The enterprise business group will drive our growth in servers and storage. Our mobile business group is in charge of continuing to grow our smartphone and tablet businesses aggressively. And our ecosystem, cloud service business group, will continue to drive monetization as well as applications and software for the best user experience.
Our new structure will go into effect on April 1 to drive even more efficiency, growth and innovation across all our business lines. Looking ahead, we are confident that our existing business will grow as we have committed to our shareholders. We are also confident that our newly acquired businesses will give us a solid foundation to build new pillars for long-term, sustainable growth. Thank you very much. Now let me turn to our CFO, Wai Ming.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2014
componenttext:
Thank you, Yuanqing. I will take you through Lenovo's financial and operational performance in quarter 3.
Next chart, please. We continue to have strong growth in both sales and profit with margin expansion in quarter 3. We recorded growth in all our key businesses: PCs, smartphone and tablet. Strong growth in our smartphone and tablet businesses have added an important new source of sustainable growth for the group, and MIDH business now accounts for 16% of group's turnover compared to 15% in quarter 2 and 11% a year ago.
Group sales grew 15% year-on-year to around $10.8 billion. Revenue derived from our PC and related business was up 10% year-on-year gain to $8.7 billion, driven by both shipment growth and increase in ASP. Sales in our mobile Internet business were up 73% year-on-year to $1.7 billion. Gross profit was about $1.4 billion, up 15% year-on-year. Gross profit margin dipped slightly to 12.6% from 12.7% last year and 12.9% in quarter 2. This small decline were largely due to the increased mix of the fast-growing consumer business and also the impact from a temporary interruption in the supply of casing component for our premium commercial products during the quarter.
Operating expenses increased 9% year-on-year to $1 billion in quarter 3. This includes the increase from adding new businesses, i.e., CCE and the EMC joint venture, which we only started the integration in quarter 4 last year. We have also started our efficiency improvement program early in this fiscal year with reducing resource in our PC business while redeploying the resources in our high-growth PC Plus business. This resulted in a $13 million severance expense incurred in quarter 3.
During the quarter, we recorded $22 million of profit from the liquidation of an available for sale of financial assets in quarter 3. In addition to the effects from better scaling and stringent expense control, the E/R ratio does improve from 10.1% last year and 10% last quarter to 9.5% in quarter 3.
Operating profit was $334 million, up 37% year-on-year. Increase in other nonoperating expense was mainly due to a higher financing cost from additional financing and increased factoring cost. Pretax income was $321 million, up 30% year-on-year, being the first time for it to surpass the $300 million level.
PTI margin continued to improve year-on-year and quarter-to-quarter. Effective tax rate for quarter 3 was around 17%. Profit attributable to equity holders was $265 million, up 30% year-on-year. Again, this is also a record high level for the group. 
Basic EPS improved to USD 2.56 from USD 1.99 last year.
Next chart, please. Our balance sheet in quarter 3 remains healthy. Non-current assets were about $4.7 billion, which was similar to last quarter 2. Current assets were about $14.8 billion against $13.3 billion in quarter 2, mainly due to the increase in cash and receivables, which is in line with our business growth. Inventories were relatively stable, under tight control even we continue to increase in-house manufacturing in China and Brazil, together with the consolidation of our acquisition of CCE in quarter 4.
Net current assets were around $61 million at the end of December against net liability at the end of September. The non-current liabilities were at around $1.9 billion.
Let's go through the cash and working capital in the next chart. We continue to leverage our strong cash position to support our strategic business expansion into consumer business, mobile device business and enhancing our capability through increasing in-house manufacturing mix. Adoption of this strategy impacted on our cash conversion cycle trend. As a result, the cash conversion cycle has come down to negative 2 days in Q3 against negative 5 days last year. We recorded our operating cash inflow of around $1 billion versus outflow of $189 million in last quarter 2, and $889 million in quarter 3 last year. The cash flow derived from operations is remaining very healthy in quarter 3.
With the 2 acquisitions we announced, I want to highlight our cash position for your reference. We have net cash reserve of around $3 billion and, together with the undrawn facility, around $1.7 billion, we have a total around $4.7 billion usable cash on hand. We have to pay a total of around $2.7 billion upon closing of the 2 deals and $1.5 billion 3 years after the closing of the Motorola Mobility transaction. We still have around $2 billion usable cash after the closing. We contemplate both acquisitions will operate on the negative cash conversion cycle business model and do not require significant capital investment in short term. Together with the cash flow from operations, we have very healthy cash resource to continue to fund the growth of our existing business. We're confident that we expect growth in our core business and healthy cash flow from operations. Even with the potential short-term financial impact arising from our investment in the 2 transactions, we do not expect any change in our dividend policy.
Next chart, please. We continue to do well in all geographies in Q3 for both our PC and mobile device business and our PC Plus strategy. Our balanced geographic exposure, especially markets outside China, including Americas, EMEA and Asia Pacific, continue to help contribute to our top line growth. We continue to record share gains across geographies, products and customer segments.
Results of the initial expansion of our smartphone and tablet business in markets outside China were also encouraging.
China. We continue to outperform in the China PC market despite its decline and further strengthen our #1 position with a record high market share. Our PC Plus strategy continues to work well, and both our smartphone and tablet business continue to post strong unit shipment growth.
Total revenue from China was roughly flat year-on-year. Our overall margin in China was up 0.8 points year-on-year and 0.1 points quarter-on-quarter to 5.4%. This reflected the successful execution of our "protect and attack" strategy to protect China PC profit through tighter control on pricing and expense control, which resulted in improving PC margin while continuously attacking to mobile device markets. We will continue to invest in the PC Plus area and in LTE 4G products to position ourselves well for the growth opportunities. We remain confident that our PC Plus strategy is fully operational in China and can continue to drive growth in China.
Asia Pacific. Revenue was up 22% year-on-year to about $1.6 billion in Asia Pacific, while operating profit reached $25 million in quarter 3. We continue to perform well in Japan and maintain our leadership position. But depreciation of Japanese yen has negatively impacted sales in the region. Our drive in smartphone and tablet in this region has been encouraging, and our smartphone shipments reached over 1 million units for the first time in the region. Our operating margin was up 0.4 points to 1.5% year-on-year under the strong progress in the PC Plus area.
EMEA. We continue to have very encouraging results in EMEA with record high market share. Revenue grew 25% year-on-year to about $2.9 billion. Strong growth in emerging markets and consumer business contributed to the strong growth in the region. Our mobile device business, especially tablet business in Europe, has also recorded strong growth momentum. As a result, our operating margin was up 0.2 points to 1.8% year-on-year.
Americas. We continue to achieve strong growth in the American regions. Our unit shipments grew 28% against the market decline of around 3%. Revenue was up 36% year-on-year. We continue to benefit from strong growth in both commercial and consumer businesses in North America that resulted in our market gain of 1.2 points to 10.2%. We continue to deliver strong growth in Brazil. Our integration of CCE has been on track, helping us achieve a record high market share in Brazil in quarter 3 where unit shipments increased by 3.8x year-on-year.
We continue our investment in the fast-growing Brazil and Latin America businesses, coupled with competition in PC business in the region and the impact from a temporary interruption in the supply of casing components for our premium commercial products to our North American business, the operating margin of Americas region and thus resulted in a decline.  We expect the margin in this region will recover in the next few quarters.
Next chart, please. We continue to outperform the worldwide market across PCs, smartphone and tablets, driven by our solid PC Plus transformation and strategy execution. Notebook shipments and sales were up 9% and 11% year-on-year, respectively. Unit shipments and sales in our desktop business were up 9% and up 12% year-on-year. Our MIDH business continues to show strong performance, up 73% year-on-year in sales led by the smartphone and tablet business which fueled the strong growth of the group. We will continue to invest in innovation and broaden our product portfolio to enhance our competitiveness and services to our customers.
Looking ahead, we remain confident our existing business will continue to outperform the market across our key products under the solid execution of our PC Plus strategy with margin expansion. We will continue to invest in our core PC business to lead in multiple computing, accelerate our smartphone worldwide expansion and invest to prepare for LTE in China and breakthrough in tablets. We will continue to build our enterprise product portfolio and invest in ecosystems, as well as innovation across the board.
We will stay focused on our efficiency improvement initiatives and growth opportunities of our existing business. We are confident the trend in the growth of our existing business that we have shown in the past several quarters will continue to deliver the improvement in profitability.
The 2 acquisitions, that is the IBM low-end server business and Motorola Mobility, will further strengthen our competitiveness upon closing to position us well on our next phase of growth over time. The 2 transactions are subject to regulatory approvals, and we will update the market on our progress going forward. We have started to prepare our post-merger management process in order to ensure a smooth transition after closings.
Thank you very much. Now we can take your questions.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, May 21, 2014
componenttext:
Thank you. Good evening. So do you enjoy the video? Yes, so it's our last fiscal year. So thank you for joining us today. I'm very excited to share our historical performance and our future strategy with you. 
Last quarter, we delivered outstanding results despite it being our seasonally low quarter. Revenue grew almost 20% year-on-year, while earnings increased almost 25% year-on-year to $158 million. Although China PC market was slowing down, we saw strong growth across all other 3 geos. So actually, for the first time, our EMEA geo become our largest PC geo. We also become the #1 consumer PC player in EMEA. But meanwhile, China still contributed most of our profit. We improved our -- so although our revenue didn't grow, but we improved -- in China, but we improved our PC PTI by 1 point to almost 7% there. Worldwide, not only did we strengthen our #1 PC position, but we also gained about 3 points of the market share in tablets. And we're also the world's fastest-growing major smartphone company, growing almost 60% year-on-year. For the fiscal year, our revenue reached an all-time high of nearly USD 39 billion, up 14% year-on-year. More importantly, we had record profit, with pretax income of more than USD 1 billion for the first time in our company's history. Overall, we had record earnings of USD 817 million, up almost 30% year-on-year. More impressively, we drove strong growth across all product lines. We shipped 55 million PCs, to reach our all-time high share of 17.7% worldwide. And we're the worldwide leader in every quarter of the last fiscal year. We shipped 9.2 million tablets, quadrupled our last year's volume. And we also shipped over 50 million smartphones in 26 global markets. Now we are #4 in both tablet and smartphone worldwide. We also had important success in our ecosystem business, with the Lenovo App store delivering more than 25 million downloads per day, and our SHAREit app become our first to reach the 100 million users milestone. 
So these results show the formula for success that I always talk about: clear strategy, innovative products, operational excellence and a diverse global team and culture. So this formula is clearly working. So they improve our ability to make better money in matured businesses, like PCs, and to drive growth in those that are shifting to maturity, like smartphone, tablet. So this is our stronghold because we are the best company in the world at balancing the innovation and the efficiency. Our next goal is becoming global #1 in broader PC area. Broader PC means desktop plus laptop plus tablet. So we want to become #1 in this area, so in 2 years. Now we are second place, 4 points behind the #1. So we want to catch up this gap in 2 years while building the new growth pillars in mobile and enterprise through successful integration of IBM x86 server and Motorola Mobility. Both deals are progressing through approval process. 
To stabilize its current business, IBM announced a commitment to invest $50 million more over the next 2 quarters to further drive sales and invest in business partners. Feedback from customers, channel partners have been very positive. Once the IBM deal is closed, we believe we can build a $5 billion enterprise business with higher margins than PCs in 1 year. 
On the other hand, Motorola showed a good growth last quarter, so there's just the issue that they are last quarter's earnings. The launches in key markets like India, Brazil and the U.K. have been very successful. And the new Moto products, including Moto E and Moto G LTE, so -- have been very positive. We just got news from them. So after they launched the Moto G -- Moto E in India, so actually in 2 hours, they sold out all the products. So we believe, with Lenovo's scale and our operational excellence, so we are confident to turn this business around in 4 to 6 quarters after the deal close. So this is still our expectation or plan. And once we close this deal, so we aim to sell 100 million mobile devices, including smartphones and tablets, in the coming year. 
So Lenovo has a proven track record that we turned the IBM PC business from losing hundreds of millions dollars a year to today, Lenovo's cash crop and the global leader. We have successfully integrated NEC in Japan, Medion in Germany, CCE in Brazil. We created a global team, global culture and a global winner. Now we will drive even stronger future growth in our mobile and enterprise business. So we understand that investing in these 2 new businesses or 2 acquisitions will impact our short-term performance, but we are very firm that we should do this to secure our sustainable growth. Balancing short-term and long-term performance is a true test of management commitment. 
In the year ahead, so our strategy, we are focused on protecting PCs and attacking in mobile, enterprise and the ecosystem cloud services. So Protect and Attack is still our strategy. Our Triple PLUS strategic roadmap starts with PC plus mobile to form our Smart Connected Devices portfolio. So in these products, we will leverage our innovation, strong channels and operational excellence across all devices. So when you add the servers and the storage, so you get our total device portfolio. Lenovo is one of the few companies that can offer a full range of products. Then we add the cloud product and the services to create a unique Lenovo experience to drive even more value to our customers. So that's our strategy going forward. 
So this last year was the most successful year in Lenovo's history, yet we are prepared to again unlock substantial growth in acquisitions. So with the combination of our existing and the new businesses, Lenovo offers tremendous value to our shareholders today, and our value will be even greater in the future. 
Thank you, everyone. Now let me turn this stage to Wai Ming, our CFO. Wai Ming, please?

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, May 21, 2014
componenttext:
Thank you, Yuanqing. Good evening, everybody. I will take you through the Lenovo financial and operational performance for our quarter 4 as well as the full fiscal year 2014. Next slide, please? 
Fiscal year 2014 was a year of success for Lenovo, and Q4 was another quarter, as we continue to grow in both sales and profit with margin expansion. Even more, I think cash flow from our operations has also improved significantly compared to that of last year. We recorded growth in all our key businesses and, at the same time, further improved our profitability. We finished the fiscal year with record-high revenue. Group revenue was up 14% to around $39 billion. PC sales, up 7% year-to-year to around $31.8 billion, driven by the shipment growth as well as increasing ASP. Sales in our mobile device business, up 86% year-on-year to about $5.7 billion. Gross profit for the fiscal year was about $5 billion, up 14%. Margin -- gross margin stayed flat year-to-year at 13.1%. Operating expenses increased 11% year-to-year to about $4 billion. This included a $79 million severance payment for the year as part of our efficiency improvement program. Even with that, our E/R was down year-on-year to 10.4% compared with 10.7% last year. Operating profit and pretax income surpassed the $1 billion mark and up 32% and 27%, respectively. It was the first time in our history that we have passed our PTI over $1 billion. PTI margin was 2.6% versus last year at 2.4%. Profit for the year was $817 million against $631 million, the gain up 29%. Profit attributable to equity holders was $817 million, up 29% year-to-year. We continue to be on track in our margin expansion program, announced about 7 quarters ago, to improve PTI margin by 1 percentage point in 3 years' time. 
For quarter 4, revenue was up 19% year-to-year to around $9.4 billion. Gross profit was up 18% year-to-year to $1.2 billion. Operating profit increased by 37% year-to-year to $231 million. Other nonoperating expenses was $19 million, mainly attributable to increased financing costs, including factoring as well as local borrowing costs as we further expand our business. Pretax income was $212 million, up 28% year-to-year. Profit attributable to equity holders was $158 million, up 25% year-to-year after netting off a $10 million noncontrolling interest from the profit recorded in the Compal JV in the quarter. 
Basic earnings per share is USD 0.0153 in quarter 4 and USD 0.0788 for the full year. The board decided this morning to declare a final dividend of HKD 0.18 per share. Next slide, please? 
Our balance sheet remains strong. Noncurrent assets as of 31st March 2014 was about $5 billion. The increase from the previous year was largely due to an increase of our in-house manufacturing and related facilities in China. Current assets were around $13.4 billion. Increase in inventory were largely due to the increase in our in-house manufacturing and our increased mix of our consumer business, which is in line with our business growth. Other changes in the current assets and current liabilities were due largely to our increased level of activities. Overall, our balance sheet remains healthy, despite quarter 4 typically being a low season for us. We have net current liabilities around $62 million as of 31st March 2014. The noncurrent liabilities were around $1.9 billion. Next slide, please? 
Our cash position remains very healthy. As of 31st March 2014, we have net cash of around $3.5 billion. We continue to do well in managing our working capital. For the full year, inventory days were 28 days, up 7 days against last year due to our expansion in the consumer business as well as in emerging markets and the ramp-up of our new in-house manufacturing capabilities. Receivable days was around 35 days, flat year-on-year. Payable days were 65 days, up 1 day against last year. As a result, our cash conversion cycle for the fiscal year was negative 2 days compared with negative 8 days the year before. For quarter 4, our cash conversion cycle changed from negative 7 days to negative 4 days, very similar to our full year trend. 
Our operating cash flow has improved significantly during the quarter. We have recorded net cash generated from operations around $1.4 billion for the full year versus $20 million outflow -- $20 million for the last year and 609 -- sorry, $469 million in quarter 4 this year. Again, a cash outflow of $679 million the same quarter last year. To further improve our financial position, we have issued a USD 1.5 billion 5-year notes with a coupon rate of 4.7% in early May. The notes were well received by the market. In fact, the issue is the largest ever unrated bond issuance by a non-Japanese Asian company. Our cash position remains very strong, even taking into consideration paying about $2.8 billion for the 2 acquisition at the closing. Next chart, please? 
Our balanced geographic exposure continue to help contribute to our top line growth. Strong performance in EMEA and AG, up 27% and 31%, respectively, despite sales decline in China. Markets outside China now account for around 62% of the group sales compared with 37% last year. In fact, our PC revenue in EMEA in quarter 4 has surpassed our PC business in China for the first time in our history. We continue to record share gain across geography, product and customer segments under our strategy. For China, we continue to outperform in the China PC market despite this decline and further strengthen our #1 position with a strong market share. Our strategy continue to work well, as both our smartphone and tablet business continue to post strong growth. Total revenue from China was up 1% year-on-year. Our overall margin in China, up 0.9 points year-on-year to 5.4%. This reflected the successful execution of our strategy to protect our China PC business, a profitable business, through tighter control of pricing and as well as expense control, while continuously, we attack into the mobile device market, which show significant growth in top line as well as improved profitability. For Asia Pacific, revenue up 12% year-to-year to about $6.2 billion in Asia Pacific. Operating profit recorded -- reached record high of $109 million. Strong performance in Japan, especially in the commercial PC segment, supported our overall improvement in the region. Our drive in smartphone and tablet in this region has also been encouraging, and our smartphone shipment surpassed 3 million units in the region for the fiscal year. Our operating margin, up significantly by 0.7 percentage points to 1.8% for the year due to the scaling benefit as well as expense control. For EMEA, we continue to see -- we continue to have very encouraging results in the region, with record-high market share. Revenue grew 27% year-on-year to about $9.6 billion. Strong growth in emerging markets and consumer business contributed to the strong growth in the region. We became the largest consumer PC player in the region for the first time in Q4. Our mobile business, including smartphone and tablet, in the region has also recorded strong growth momentum. The overall operating margin for the region was up 0.5 percentage points to 2%, again, due to scaling benefit as well as good expense control. For Americas, we continue to achieve strong growth in the American region. Revenue up 31% year-on-year. We benefit from the strong growth in both commercial as well as the commercial business in North America, resulting our market share gain of 1.7 points to a record high to 10.5%. In quarter 4, we became the #3 player in the U.S. market, the first time for the group. We also continue to deliver strong growth in Brazil. Operating margin of the American region was down 0.5 points year-to-year to 0.08% (sic) [0.8%], which was mainly due to the increased consumer business exposure, as well as there is an impact on the mechanical power supply interruption affecting our North American business, sadly, in quarter 3. However, the issue largely been fixed in quarter 4, and we're happy to see operating margin of our North American business has recovered. Meanwhile, we continue our investment in the fast-growing Brazil and Latin America business to build our foundation. Next chart, please?
We have a more balanced product portfolio, helped by our expansion in consumer PC and mobile device business, with growth and share gain in each of those key devices. The revenue contribution for the mobile device business increased to 15% this year compared with 9% last year, with improving profitability. I want to take this opportunity to report the status of our 2 recent corporate transactions. Both transactions are still pending approval from the relative authorities, and we expect both transactions to close in quarter 3. We have started our post-merger management work so as to ensure a smooth transaction after the closings, which will enable us to secure the planned synergy resulting from a seamless integration from day 1 after close. Looking ahead, we believe our existing business will continue to outperform the market across our key products under the solid execution of our strategy, and we will continue our margin improvements. For our PC business, we'll continue to invest in branding and innovation in order to enable us to continue to outperform the market. However, performance may vary in different geographies or regions depending on their respective general economic environment. Smartphone and enterprise business are key to enable our continuing growth, and we'll invest to build our enterprise business and accelerate our smartphone worldwide expansion and to prepare for LTE 4G products in China. In the meantime, we'll begin to invest in the ecosystem and cloud services to support the further growth of our device business. We will stay focused on our efficiency improvement initiative and growth opportunities of our existing business. We are very confident the trend in the growth of our existing business that we have shown in the past several years will continue to deliver the improvement in profitability. Addition to the 2 businesses, after the final approvals, will definitely further strengthen the company's competitiveness in driving a sustainable growth in the next several years. 
Thank you very much. Let me now take your questions.

componenttext: Good morning. Good evening. Welcome to Lenovo's Q1 Result Webcast. This is Gary Ng, VP in Investor Relations at Lenovo. headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 14, 2014
componenttext:
Hello, everyone. I'm very happy to share our last quarter's results with you. This has been a quarter of many milestones for Lenovo. So let's jump right into it. This last quarter, our revenue grew 18% year-on-year, while our earnings increased 23% to USD 214 million. We continue to deliver our financial commitments, especially on improving profitability. Our strong performance was driven by growth across all product lines and all geos. In PCs, we gained almost 3 points of share to reach our all-time high of nearly 20%, and to strengthen our position as the worldwide leader. We gained share in every geo. In tablets, we hit a new milestone. With 67% year-on-year growth, Lenovo become #3 in the world for the first time. We are particularly strong in Eastern Europe. In Russia, we become #1. In combined PCs and tablets, we closed the gap with Apple to just 0.7 points.
As I said the last quarter, becoming #1 in the PC plus tablet category in 2 years is our goal. Well, we might not need that long. In smartphones, we become #1 in China for the first time. Our strong performance was driven by demand for our new smartphones, as China transitions to 4G and by expanding our routes to market. Even better, we saw hypergrowth outside of China at 350% year-on-year, especially in Southeast Asia, Eastern Europe and Latin America. Respectively, they grew nearly 300%, over 500% and 50%. Eastern Europe and Southeast Asia also had good profitability at 4% and 3%, respectively. Now almost 20% of our smartphone volume came from outside China, up from just 5% a year ago.
Overall, we are #4 in smartphones worldwide with sales in 36 countries. We also saw continued growth in our newest businesses. Our enterprise business had a volume growth of more than 33% year-on-year, and our ecosystem business continues to grow with the daily downloads now over 27 million. And after SHAREit, SECUREit become our second app with more than 100 million users.
Our business results have never been as balanced as today. Only 3 years ago, China was almost half of our revenue, but now even though our China business keeps growing, it's just over 1/3 of our revenue. That's because EMEA, Americas and Asia-Pacific geos, all have achieved rapid growth and gained strong momentum. In particular, EMEA volume grew more than 50% year-on-year. The last time we saw such an incredible growth rate was in China back in 2010. We only started our consumer business in EMEA 3 years ago, but now we are #1 in consumer PC there. In Americas, the U.S., was a star performer. In PC, we had a record market share. And Asia-Pacific delivered significant improvements in profitability, fueled by Japan, which has become our new profit pool for Lenovo. So even as the emerging markets faced some challenges, Lenovo's overall business is healthy, growing steadily, and you can expect the future to be even better.
These results clearly show that our formula for success, clear strategy, innovative products, operational excellence, and the diverse culture, global team continues to work. And our balance of innovation and efficiency is a core strength. We will apply our strengths to successfully integrate both Motorola Mobility and IBM x86 server business. Both deals remain on schedule for closing.
For Motorola, they are already winning in the market, and their recent results show why they can be our growth engine for Lenovo in the future. Not only is the product portfolio is strong, but also, the results are improving significantly with sellout [ph] product launches in key markets like India and Brazil and the rave reviews for the premium products that are driving growths in mature markets. Once our acquisition is complete, we will be able to bring more innovative products to more customers worldwide. We remain confident we can turn it around in 4 to 6 quarters after the deal closes.
For IBM x86, we have seen the business stabilize in the last quarter. In particular, they achieved continuous growth in China. We remain confident that once the IBM deal is closed, we can build a $5 billion enterprise business with a higher margin than PCs in 1 year. Both acquisitions will further strengthen Lenovo to grow across all lines of businesses.
In PCs, with the market becoming stabilized, we expect our strong growth to continue worldwide, especially outside of China because market share there are still lower. We will strengthen our position in every geo by leveraging both our momentum and the opportunity from industry consolidation to drive profitable growth.
In tablets, as we predicted 2 years ago, the market is squeezed by convertible PC on the high end and by a phablet on the low end. In the future, it may not be an independent category. It will be split into 2 categories, either a low-end niche PC, focusing on media consumption, which includes 8-inch or bigger, some with an optional attached keyboards or a big-screen smartphone, phablets. We are strong in both parts, and we launched a new generation of exciting products to attack both categories in the second half of this year.
In smartphones, the market continues to shift from premiere to mainstream entry segments, and we definitely know how to leverage this strength as we have done in the PC stage. In the intensively competitive China market, we are working to solidify our #1 position by our taking in premier price spend [ph] and by expanding our routes to market through the open market and the online channels. Meanwhile, we will be more aggressive in emerging markets, which is our stronghold and where we see even more opportunity.
Finally, we will integrate Motorola to make us an even stronger worldwide player. Definitely, the first quarter gave us momentum, and we are off to a strong start. We are well positioned in all product lines and geos to not only grow share but also increase profitability. And while our acquisitions close, we will be fully ready to compete across all smart connected devices, infrastructure devices and in the ecosystem space.
Thank you, everyone. Now let me turn this to our CFO, Wai Ming. Wai Ming, please?

componenttext:
Thank you, Yuanqing. I will take you through Lenovo's financial and operational performance in quarter 1. Next chart, please. We continue to grow in both sales and profit with margin expansion by shipment growth. Even more, cash flow from our operation has also improved significantly compared to the same quarter last year. We recorded growth in all our key businesses and at the same time, further improved our profitability.
Group sales grew 18% year-on-year to around $10.4 billion. Our mobile device business, including phones and tablets, were up 32% year-on-year to $1.6 billion. PC and personal technology product-related sales were up 16% year-on-year to around $8.5 billion. Sales of other goods and services were $294 million, up about 6% year-on-year.
Gross profit for quarter 1 was about $1.3 billion, up 13% year-on-year. Gross profit margin was 13% against 13.6% last year. The decrease was due to the increased mix from faster-growing consumer business, as well as changing geographic mix.
Operating expense increased by 8% to $1.1 billion. This included $4 million severance expenses incurred for the year as part of the efficiency improvement program. Even with that, our E/R improved from 11.3% to 10.3% due to scaling benefits and strengthened expense control.
Operating profit in quarter 1 was $283 million, up 40% year-on-year. We recorded non-operating expenses of $90 million, which included interest expenses of $10.5 million accrue for the USD 1.5 billion 5-year notes with a coupon rate of 4.7% we issued in early May.
Profit for the period was to $211 million, up 24%. Profit attributable to equity holders were $214 million, up 23% year-on-year. The difference between the 2 profit lines was due to our joint venture partner sharing of loss in relation to the Compal JV.
Next chart, please. Our balance sheet remains strong. Non-current asset were about $5.2 billion, and current assets were about $15.5 billion as of 30th of June 2014. Increasing bank deposit in cash was largely due to that cash obtained from the U.S. dollar note issuance in May this year, where net current assets are around $1.5 billion at the end of June. The non-current liabilities were at around $3.4 billion.
Now let's go through the cash and working capital in the next chart. Our cash position remained very healthy. As the end of June, we have net cash of around $3.6 billion. The quarter-to-quarter increase of our bank deposits and cash was mainly due to the $1.5 billion cash raised from the U.S. dollar notes.
We continue to do well in managing our working capital for quarter 1. Inventory days were at 28, up 1 day against last year due to our continuous expansion into the consumer business and emerging markets and ramp-up [ph] of our new in-house manufacturing. Receivable days were 32, decreased 4 days year-on-year. Payable days were 66 days, reduced by 2 days against last year. As a result, the cash conversion cycle for the quarter was at negative 6 days, again, a negative 1 day last year. The quarter-on-quarter change is largely due to the growth of our commercial business.
Our operating cash flow has improved significantly during the quarter. We have recorded net cash generated from operations of around $378 million in quarter 1 against $140 million the same quarter last year. We remain at a very strong cash position for working capital needs to drive future growth.
Next chart, please. As Yuanqing just highlighted, we continue to record share gain across geographies, products and customer segments under our strategy. And our balanced geographic exposure continued to help contribute to our top line growth. Strong revenue growth of EMEA and AP helped drive top line growth despite China PC industry still experience a decline. And at the same time, both regions record a significant improvement in their operating margins. They both achieved their record high levels driven by strong growth.
The revenue from China was up about 2% year-on-year driven by the balanced growth between our PC and mobile device businesses. We continue to protect our profit pool, and our China overall margin fully improved by 0.3 points year-on-year to 5.5%.
Our PC revenue show a year-on-year growth of about 1%, as we further strengthened our #1 position with a strong market share and continued to outperform in the China PC market despite its decline. Our China PC operating margin improved by 0.2 points year-on-year to 7%.
Smartphone continues to demonstrate strong growth momentum. In quarter 1, we surpassed Samsung to become #1 in China smartphone market for the first time, and the profitability of our mobile device business continued to improve in the quarter. We continued to solidify our China smartphone business and focus on profitable growth in this highly competitive market. In order to enhance our competitiveness, we invest in product innovation in the 4G smartphone and further broaden routes to market.
Asia-Pacific, revenue was up 20% year-on-year to about $1.6 billion in Asia-Pacific region. Strong performance in Japan, especially in the commercial PC business, supported our overall improvement in the region. Our drive in smartphone, particularly in the ASEAN regions, has continued to be encouraging. Our operating margin was up significantly by 3.2 percentage points to a record high level of 4.1% driven by the growth in scale for both PC and mobile device businesses.
EMEA. We have excellent results in EMEA with record high market share and improvement in profitability. Revenue grew 49% year-on-year to about $2.8 billion. Strong growth in the emerging markets and consumer business contributed to the strong growth in the region. Our mobile device business, including smartphone and tablet business in EMEA, has also recorded strong growth momentum. And it was the first time our smartphone shipment exceeded 1 million units. The overall EMEA operating margin was up significantly by 1.9 percentage point to 3.4% due to the scaling benefit from the strong growth and expense control.
Americas. We continue to achieve a strong growth premium against the market decline in the region with record high share at about 12.5%. We continue to record strong growth in the U.S. to a record high market share of 11.3% with margin improvements. The revenue of the Americas region grew 19% year-on-year driven by growth across all products and regions. Operating margin, however, was down year-on-year, and we're still investing in Brazil and the Latin American regions.
We have a much more balanced geographic mix today. Sales mix of China dropped to 36% compared to 42% same quarter last year. We believe our strong momentum in markets outside of China will continue to support a growth above market performance. Our share in these markets are still low, and we're confident to continue to deliver strong growth and will contribute to the margin improvement, benefiting from the better scaling.
Next chart, please. We have a more balanced product portfolio helped by our expansion in the consumer PC and mobile device business. Notebook shipments were up around 17%, was a 21-point premium to the market, and sales were up 12% year-on-year, respectively. Unit shipments and sales in our desktop business were up 12% and 20%, respectively, year-on-year. Our mobile device business continue to show strong performance with revenue grew 32% year-on-year, among which, smartphone shipments were up 39% year-on-year, and our tablet shipments were up 67% year-on-year.
Looking ahead, we believe our existing business will continue to outperform the market across our key products under the solid execution of our strategy with margin improvement. We are confident to continue to outperform the PC market, while, at the same time, we'll also benefit from the gradually recovering market. We'll continue to solidify our leadership position in the China smartphone market and improved its profitability. And at the same time, we'll grow aggressively in the emerging market.
Our post-merger management office has been on the ground in closely liaising with our counterparties to ensure the integration work of the 2 transactions on day 1 post closing can be carried out seamlessly, and the planned synergy can be delivered. We will stay focused on our efficiency improvement initiatives and growth opportunity of our existing business. 
We are confident the trend and the growth of our existing business that we have shown in the past several years will continue to deliver the improvement in profitability. Addition of the 2 businesses after the final approvals will further strengthen the group's competitiveness in driving sustainable growth in the next several years.
Thank you. Now we can take your questions.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2014
componenttext:
Good morning, and good evening. Welcome to Lenovo's Q2 Earnings Announcement Webcast. This is Gary Ng, VP of Investor Relations at Lenovo. Today, I'm pleased to have our Chairman and CEO, Mr. Yang Yuanqing; and our CFO, Mr. Wong Wai Ming, with us. We will first start with our presentation. After that, we'll take your questions. 
Now let me turn it over to Yuanqing. Yuanqing, please.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2014
componenttext:
Hello, everyone. We just completed a historic month, closing both the IBM System x and the Motorola acquisitions. But before I discuss that, I first want to share our strong second quarter results with you.
This quarter, our revenue grew by 7% year-on-year, while our earnings increased almost 20% to USD 262 million. We continue to deliver our commitment to improving profitability, thanks to strong performance across our entire businesses.
In PCs, we gained more than 2 points of the share to reach an all-time high of nearly 20% and strengthened our position as the worldwide leader. In tablets, we gained almost 1 point of the share year-on-year and are now #3 worldwide. Actually, just a few weeks ago, when a company from Cupertino launched these new tablets, they talked about how they sold more tablets than any manufacturer sold PCs. But this is not a fair comparison. You could say this is comparing apples and oranges. You could compare apples to apples. You could compare oranges to oranges, or if you want to reflect the overall, you could compare the far apple plus oranges.
A couple of years ago, when the same company talked about how tablets would cannibalize PCs, we predicted that tablet would actually be cannibalized by convertible PCs and the large-screen smartphones. So we doubled down on these 2 areas and set the target to win in both smartphone and, separately, broad PC, tablet plus PC.
At the end of last fiscal year in May, we told you our next milestone was to become #1 in broad PC in 2 years. Instead, we did it in 2 quarters. This is the latest IDC data, so you can see not only how the market has evolved and responded, but also how Lenovo has performed even better than planned. In smartphones, we remain the #4 in the world. But of course, once we add the Motorola, we will be #3. Although we are facing some challenges in China, we still achieved a record sales volume because of our rapid expansion outside of China over the past 2 years.
Today, our smartphones are selling in more than 45 countries. India and the Southeast Asia, Russia and the EMEA emerging markets, Latin America were all our stars. Respectively, their unit grew about 120%, 400% and 150%.
Overall, 1/3 of our revenue -- smartphone revenue comes from outside of China, more than doubled from a year ago. We also continue to drive growth in our enterprise business, where volume increased by 35% year-on-year. Finally, our ecosystem business also continue to grow as the daily downloads are now over 30 million.
Our strong results show that our formula for success, clear strategy, innovative products, operational excellence and a diverse team global culture continues to work. And we have proven our unique ability to balance innovation and efficiency across all our business groups.
Now we will apply this strength to drive even greater growth. As we integrate both Motorola Mobility and System x, the success for closing of these 2 big deals gives Lenovo a strong position in 2 new areas: mobile and enterprise.
Last year, we had a vision and a strategy to grow beyond PCs, but not all the PCs we needed. Now we will go to all of them. With these 2 deals, we are now #3 in both businesses, but we are not satisfied. We will replicate our success in PCs by outgrowing the market to challenge the top 2. Mobile and enterprise are now our new growth engines. And over time, they will become our profit pool as well. In enterprise, we are focused on growing revenue and leveraging Lenovo's efficient supply chain to reduce cost. We remain very confident that we can build our $5 billion enterprise business with profits higher than PCs in 1 year.
For smartphones, it's the perfect time to close Moto. Over the years, we have owned in China, we actually have been in the top 2 for 10 quarters in a row. But now the China market is not hyper growing any longer. It has been saturated. If you want to win, you must find a new growth area. You must become a true global player. This is what we have now become with Motorola. We will operate in all key markets, including mature markets, the U.S., Western Europe; and the emerging markets, India and the Southeast Asia, Russia and the EMEA emerging, Brazil and the rest of Latin America.
At the same time, we are still very committed to the China market. To address changes there, while still maintaining our advantage in traditional channels, including carrier market, we are building a new Internet-based company to capture the new market opportunity there. Our execution, acquisitions and the new business initiatives will drive growth.
We will also grow through innovation like we did when we created the Yoga notebooks and tablets. We launched the latest generations last month. With these new star products, we will continue to lead in convertibles and drive growth in tablets. And we are heading even more innovative products, including the new Lenovo VIBE smartphones; System x's server lines; and Moto's impressive new family of products, the new Moto X, Moto 360 watch android [ph] and a stylish Hint Bluetooth device.
Our strong performance demonstrates our clear momentum. Now the additions of Motorola and the System x teams allow us to compete and to grow across all smart connected devices, infrastructure devices and in the ecosystem space. 
Thank you, everyone. Now let me turn this to our CFO, Wai Ming. Wai Ming, please.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2014
componenttext:
Thank you, Yuanqing. I would take you through Lenovo's financial and operational performance in Q2. Next chart, please. We continue to grow in both sales and profit with margin expansion. Moreover, cash flow from our operations has also improved compared to the same quarter last year. We recorded growth in most of our key businesses and, at the same time, further improved our profitability. Group sales grew 7% year-on-year to around $10.5 billion. PC and other nonmobile device personal technology products-related sales were up 10% year-on-year to around $8.8 billion. Our mobile device business, including phones and tablets, was down 6% year-on-year to $1.4 billion. Sales of other goods and services were $292 million, declining about 9% year-to-year.
Gross profit for quarter 2 was about $1.5 billion, up 15% year-on-year. Gross profit margin was 13.9% against 12.9% last year. The increase was mainly attributed to the increased mix of higher-margin PC products and the shift in geographic mix. Operating expenses increased by 11% to around $1.1 billion. The increase was primarily driven by the one-off M&A expenses related to System x and Moto transactions. Hence, the E/R ratio increased from 10% last year to 10.4% in quarter 2.
Operating profit in quarter 2 was $365 million, up 29% year-on-year. We recorded nonoperating expenses of $36 million, which included the interest expenses of $18.1 million accrued for the USD 1.5 billion 5-year notes we issued in early May. Profit for the period was $272 million, up 27%. Profit attributable to equity holders was $262 million, up 19% year-on-year. The difference between the 2 profit lines was due to our joint venture partners sharing of gain in relation to Compal's joint venture versus losses recorded last year.
Basic EPS improved to USD 0.0252 from USD 0.0212 last year. The Board of Directors in today's meeting declared an interim dividend of HKD 0.06, represent the same level of interim dividend paid last year.
Despite the additional charges arising from the amortization of intangible assets of the 2 acquisitions, we contemplate to maintain our level of dividend payments. Next chart, please.
Our policy remains strong. Noncurrent assets was about $5.2 billion, and current assets were about $16.4 billion as of 30 of September 2014. The increase of current assets were attributed to the increase in receivables, which was largely in line with our business growth. We had net current assets of around $1.6 billion at the end of September. The noncurrent liabilities were at around $3.8 billion. Let's go through the cash and working capital in the next chart.
Our cash position remain very healthy. As of end of September, we had net cash of around $3.2 billion. The quarter-on-quarter decrease of our bank deposits and cash was mainly due to payment of final dividend for fiscal year '14 in our Q2. We continue to do well in managing our working capital for quarter 2. Inventory days were at 30, up 2 days against last year due to our continuous expansion into consumer business in emerging market and the ramp-up of our new in-house manufacturing. Receivable days were at 34 days, which remained flat year-on-year. Payable days were at 69 days, increasing by 4 days against last year. As a result, the cash conversion cycle for the quarter was at negative 5 days. Again, negative 3 days last year. The slight quarter-on-quarter change is largely due to the strong growth of our consumer business.
We have recorded net cash generated from operations of $280 million in quarter 2, against, net cash outflow of $189 million in the same quarter last year. The year-on-year and quarter-on-quarter changes are mainly due to changes in net working capital and relevant foreign exchange impacts. Our cash flow from operation remain healthy to continue to drive our future growth. Next chart, please. 
Our geographic exposure is even more balanced to support our future sustainable growth. 
China. Despite a strong performance from our PC business, which recorded a 6% year-to-year increase of our revenue against the market shipment decline of 3%, the total revenue from China was down 2% year-on-year, primarily driven by a decline of non-PC business. Despite the challenging market conditions, we continue to protect our profit pool, and our China overall margin further improved by 0.5 points year-on-year to 5.8%. We recorded a market share of 37%, and we further strengthened our #1 position in China PC markets. As a result, our China PC operating margin improved by 0.02 points (sic) [0.2 points] year-on-year to 7%. Revenue of non-PC business, consist of smartphone and tablets, were down. This was attributed to the following 3 factors: One, we have more shipments towards the end of the quarter, partly due to the launching of 2 new products, VIBE X2 and S90, in late September as well as preparing for a better business in Golden Week in October. These shipments would not be recorded as Q2 revenue as a result of our accounting policy on goods already shipped, but not received by customers. Number two, during the quarter, our mix of sales in Tiered 4 to 6 cities increased as a result of our stronger partnership with carriers. This resulted to a longer lead time between sell-ins and sellouts. Under our accounting policy, we do not recognize revenue when a channel holds more than a reasonable level of inventory. And the third factor, the average selling price declined in the quarter as a result of having a larger mix of lower-priced products in the Tier 4 to 6 cities. Going forward, Lenovo new products, like VIBE X2 and S90, were well received. And together with the relaunch of Moto brand products in China, we believe we can further drive sales momentum. Finally, to address the smartphone market challenges, we will continue to broaden our risk to market, develop online channels, in addition to building the open market.
Asia Pacific. Revenue was up 3% year-on-year to about $1.6 billion in Asia Pacific. Strong performance in ASEAN's PC market supported our overall improvement in the region. We continue to see improvement in both turnover and profitability for most of the countries both year-on-year and quarter-to-quarter. Our drive in smartphone, particularly in the ASEAN region, has continued to be encouraging. Our smartphone shipment has achieved 1.5 million units in the region. Our operating margin was up significantly by 2.7 percentage points to a record high level of 4.4%, driven by growth in scale for both PC and mobile device businesses.
EMEA. Our performance in EMEA is outstanding with record high market share and operating margin expansion. Revenue grew 33% year-on-year to about $3 billion. Strong growth in emerging markets and the consumer business contributed to the strong growth in the region. Our mobile business, including smartphone and tablet businesses in EMEA, has also recorded a strong growth momentum with our smartphone shipments reached 1.6 million units. The overall EMEA operating margin was up significantly by 2.3 percentage points to 3.8% due to a scaling benefit from strong growth and expense control.
Americas. Our North America business continued to perform well and outperformed the market with market share gain. Our operating profit increased almost by 45% year-on-year. However, our business in Latin America, primarily Brazil, continued to be impacted by the weakened markets, driven by the local macroeconomic and political conditions, which dragged down our overall performance in the Americas. The new local management team has already taken actions to stabilize the business. The revenue of the Americas region was roughly flat year-on-year. Operating margin, as a result, was down year-on-year. Excluding the impact from Brazil, Americas recorded an improvement of over 12% year-on-year in revenue and recorded a 4.1% PTI margin, which represent 2 percentage points gain year-on-year. Next chart, please.
We had market share in notebook at about 21%. Notebook unit shipments were up around 14%, growing at a 13-point premium to the market. And sales were up 9% year-on-year. Our desktop PC volume also achieved a record high market share at about 18%. Unit shipments and sales in our desktop business were up 6% and 11%, respectively, year-on-year. Our mobile device business continued to show strong performance. Despite the China market continued to be challenging, our smartphone expansion in markets outside China has also been strong. Shipments were up more than 2x year-on-year. Our non-China business now account for 20% of our smartphone shipment compared to only 9% a year ago. I explained earlier about the smartphone business in China that dragged down the sales revenue in short term in quarter 2. Our tablet shipments were up 31% year-on-year, and its performance in markets like EMEA was particularly impressive. Looking ahead, we are confident that our existing business will continue to outperform the market across our key products to drive profit growth with margin expansion.
With the completion of our acquisition of the System x server business and Motorola Mobility, we will now focus on integration of the 2 transactions in the near term in order to build a solid foundation for our business. We believe these 2 transactions will sharpen our competitiveness in the mobile and enterprise business, which will become growth engines for the company over time, in addition to our core PC businesses.
We will continue to stay focused on our efficiency improvement initiatives to ensure profitable growth. We've closed the 2 major transactions in October. The results of the 2 businesses will be included in our coming Q3. Under HKFRS, out of the total consideration of $5.2 billion, approximately 50% will be classified as intangible assets, such as patented technology, customer relations, trademarks and others, which will have to be amortized over the estimated useful life. Currently, such amortization expenses are estimated to be approximately $230 million to $300 million per year, which will be recorded as an expense item. From Q3 onwards, we will provide additional disclosure on these items in order to help the market better understand about the company's underlying operational performance.
Thank you. Now we can take your questions.

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2014
componenttext: So Gokul, I think, to answer your questions, I think the 20%, as we -- I think, at -- the 20% you mentioned, that was primarily reflected in the financials of Motorola, I think, last year. And as you know, Moto G has been a fantastic success, I think, in the market. So they also -- have been also successful in, I think, in countries like India. Definitely, the -- I think the margin of Moto G and the margin of the previous years of 20% probably will have a difference, but that's not a significant difference. Because I think when you really look at the overall P&L, I think when you launch a higher-premium product, you obviously will come along with higher advertising and marketing cost. When you actually launch Moto G, which I think the market immediately see the value because of the quality of the product, I think the better user experience. I think, although the gross will -- gross margin will come down a little bit, but the net-net is actually not necessarily that different. So overall, I think we are still very, very -- I think the key for us is really looking at the growth in top line as well as the control of the expenses, and that's really the way to lead to a breakeven. I think one is I think the continued growth in the top line as far as controlling expenses. More important is I think the synergy that's derived out of the ownership because we obviously will have a much bigger overall smartphone business, and there will be improvement in terms of material costs as well as, I think, the back-end of the operation with a very efficient operating platform of Lenovo as reflected in our legacy business. You definitely can see that we'd be able to, I think, improve the gross profits, I think, if you want to be very specific, without really -- without necessarily increasing the expenses. And as a result of that, I think it would drive to a breakeven, and the plan will remain, I think, with the sort of 4 to 6 quarters. headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2014

headline: Lenovo Group Limited, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2014

componenttext: So we definitely are still committed to the China market. We are definitely confident that we will keep in the top 2.
